section.title: Tutorial2: Navigating object details pages
section.para: This tutorial will guide you through the structure of the object details pages and how to navigate them. The object details page for the zen gene will be used as an example. All object details pages have the same basic structure and so this example can be extended to other items in the database.
Enter the gene symbol 'zen' into the quick search box to access the object details page for this gene. See tutorial1 for more information on the quick search.
The object details page contains the following sections:

Summary for selected gene: The left-hand side of the object details page always provides a summary of the item being viewed. This summary includes the main attributes of the item. For genes, the main attributes are the identifier, name, symbol and organismDbID. The organismDbID is the main identifier of the relevant model organsim database - ie FlyBase for any Drosophila melanogaster genes, and so for fly genes, this attribute will always be an FBgn identifier. The 'identifier' attribute contains any main secondary identifer used for that particular organism. For D. melanogaster genes this is the CGXXXX identifier.

Further information for this gene: Below the summary is always a section for further information. This contains links to external databases where appropriate - a link is provided to the relevant gene report in FlyBase for D. melanogaster genes. Below the external links is an inset of the GBrowse genome viewer. This will be present on the object details page for any genomic feature. Click on the GBrowse image to go to the full genome browser, from where you can add additional tracks of information and naviaagte around the genome.

Other information: The right hand side of the object details page always contains a set of summary tables and links to related items. Any data not available for the particular item being viewed will be greyed and crossed out. For example, the zen gene has no clone or microArrayResult information:
For each related item, there is a summary and a link to the details page for that item. Expand the GoAnnotations and Proteins links for the zen gene to see the summary tables for these related items:
From the protein summary table, click on the [details...] link. This will take you to the object details page for the ZEN1_DROME protein:

Notice that the layout of the object details page for the ZEN1_DROME protein is the same as that for the zen gene. Notice the 'trail' in the top left hand corner above the summary. This allows you to see where you have navigated from. Clicking on the 'gene' link of the trail will take you back to the zen gene object details page.

Look at the links to items related to the ZEN1_PROTEIN. Notice that here there are several links to useful protein-based information. Notice that there is also a link back to the zen gene. Expand the links for 'Interactions' and 'proteinFeatures' to view the summary tables for the related items. The proteinFeatures link contains family and domain information for the ZEN1_DROME protein (from Interpro). Click on the [details...] link for one of the domains, to navigate to its object details page. Use the 'trail' to go back to the ZEN1_DROME protein.

Click on the [details...] link from the Regions link. FlyMine contains modelled 3-D structural predictions for certain regions of D. melanogaster proteins. The regions roughly correspond to Pfam domains. The regions link allows you to access the structural information for any regions which have been modelled. From the ProteinRegion object details page, expand the 'object', 'proteinFeature' and 'structure' links to view the domain and location for which a structure was modelled and information about the actual modelled structure. Follow the [details...] link for the 'modelledProteinStructure' for more details about the structure:

Use the 'trail' to navigate back to the zen gene object details page. The above should have given you an idea of how to navigate around and browse the database via the object details pages for related items in the database.

Underneath each object details page is a set of related template queries. These templates are queries that can be run with the type of item you are viewing and will be set to run with the identifier of the item you are viewing. (note: this does not necessarily mean there will be results available for the particular item you are viewing). See tutorial2 for more details on running template queries.
